column1: Bosnians protest against Croatia's plans for a radioactive waste disposal facility

On Friday hundreds of people gathered in north-western Bosnia in protest against plans of neighboring Croatia to store part of the waste from the only nuclear power plant in the region near the border with Bosnia and the main river known for its natural beauty.
The demonstrators in Bosnian town Novi Grad demanded that Croatia abandon its plans to build a landfill site in the former military barracks in Trgovska Gora and declared a fight against the project.
The facility would store waste from the Krško nuclear power plant.

The Bosnians, holding banners that read "I want a healthy future" and "Stop - (river) Una needs us," said that the radioactive landfill could endanger the Una River and the lives of about 250,000 inhabitants.
We must say NO,
Miroslav Drljaca, mayor of Novi Grad municipality, told the crowd.
We must fight to protect our way of life and our Una.
The Krško power plant located in Slovenia, built in the 1980s, also belongs to Croatia.
Representatives of both countries are to meet next week to discuss additional landfills.

The Croatian public television HRT reported on Friday that it has not yet been decided in Croatia whether to build a landfill site on its own or to pay for storing part of the waste in a new facility built by Slovenia.

The Croatian Minister of Environment and Energy Tomislav Coric told journalists that Croatia also has a problem with the disposal of institutional waste from schools, hospitals and prisons and hopes to find a comprehensive solution.
In Bosnia, activists, officials and residents on each side of the country's ethnic division insisted that Croatia should find a different location in a part of the country closer to the power plant.
Why does Croatia, with all its territory, claim that Trgovska Gora in Bosnia is the best place? - asked Drljac.
We cannot let them humiliate us!
The Law on the State Committee for Paedophilia has come into force
The provisions of the Act are valid from Thursday.

According to them, the committee's tasks will include issuing decisions on entry in the Sexual Offenders Register, notification of suspected paedophilia offences to the relevant authorities, but also cases of failure to notify the relevant authority of suspected paedophilia offences.
The Commission will also identify negligence and omissions in explaining cases of sexual abuse.

It concerns negligence and omissions of state bodies, non-governmental organizations, entities and institutions conducting educational, educational, caring, cultural and physical culture, leisure and treatment activities, as well as professional self-governments, churches and religious associations, including church legal persons and private persons.
The committee's task will also be to conduct preventive and educational activities.
The Commission is to be a body independent of other state authorities.

It is to be composed of seven members: three, appointed by the Sejm by a three-fifths majority in the presence of at least half of the statutory number of deputies; one, appointed by the Senate by a three-fifths majority in the presence of at least half of the statutory number of senators; and one member each appointed by the President, the Prime Minister and the Ombudsman.
Members of the committee will have to, among other things, have a higher legal, medical or psychological education and "enjoy a good reputation".
The committee may not include, among others, Members of Parliament, Senators, Members of the European Parliament and persons holding a leading state position.

Among the entities that will be able to nominate candidates for members of the committee were indicated: The Supreme Bar Council, the National Council of Legal Advisers, the National Council of the Judiciary, the National Council of Prosecutors, the Supreme Chamber of Physicians and Dentists, the National Chamber of Psychologists and non-governmental organizations whose statutory tasks for at least two years included activities related to children's rights, in particular those related to the protection and prevention of violence, including sexual violence.
Candidates for members of committees appointed by the Sejm may also be proposed by the Speaker of the Sejm or at least 35 members.
In turn, candidates for a member of the Committee appointed by the Senate may also be proposed by the Speaker of the Senate or at least 7 senators.
The chairman of the committee will be elected - from among the members of the committee - by the Sejm by a simple majority of votes.
The commission's term of office will be seven years.
A representative of the ombudsman will be able to participate in the work of the committee, in an advisory capacity and at the invitation of the chairman.
According to the law, "anyone may report to the Commission a suspicion of sexual abuse or a suspicion of failure to notify the competent authority of a suspected sexual abuse".
The notification may be made in writing, orally into the minutes or by electronic means.
Such a report is to be immediately forwarded to the public prosecutor's office competent for the place of residence of the injured party.
In the case of initiating court proceedings, the committee has the right to inspect court files and obtain information about the proceedings.
The Commission may also participate in the proceedings as an auxiliary prosecutor (with the consent of the injured party or his legal guardian).
The first report is to be prepared and made available by the committee within one year from the date of entry into force of the law.
The American Congress has agreed to sell 32 F-35 aircraft to Poland

The U.S. Congress for the statutory 15 days after the State Department approved the possible purchase by Poland of 32 F-35 multi-purpose fighters did not object to this transaction, which means that the last condition was met before the purchase negotiations began.
The decision of the Congress, although not unexpected, has great political significance.

After the approval of the sale by the State Department, and now by Congress, I see no major obstacles, said John V. Venable, Senior Defence Policy Advisor to the Washington Conservative Heritage Foundation think tank.

The expert explained that under the Arms Export Control Act of 1976, the Federal Government, represented by the State Department, must notify Congress of any planned sale of arms abroad 15 days before signing a contract, if the value of such a transaction, in the case of selling arms to a NATO member country, exceeds $50 million.

The value of the proposed purchase of 32 F-35 fighters by Poland is estimated at USD 6.5 billion. This amount includes the costs of technical and logistical assistance, auxiliary equipment and pilot training.

The main supplier of F-35 planes - if this transaction is finally completed - will be the American armaments company Lockheed Martin, and its subcontractor is the F-35A fighter engine manufacturer Pratt and Whitney.
Proposals to purchase the fifth generation F-35 American fighters on behalf of the Polish authorities were submitted in May by Minister of Defense Mariusz Błaszczak.
The Polish offer was discussed in June this year during a meeting between President Andrzej Duda and President Donald Trump at the White House.
The implementation of this agreement, if it is finalized, will be supervised by representatives of the Pentagon within the framework of the Foreign Military Sales Program (FMS).
As part of the FMS program, Poland has already acquired, among others, the Patriot anti-missile system.
The price of one F-35 fighter was about 89.2 million dollars without weapons and technical assistance at the time of the Polish bid.
As American military experts who wished to remain anonymous informed the PAP, such a price given in the preliminary negotiations was "the maximum price, much higher than the price to be negotiated".
Prices are falling sharply, currently the price of one F-35 is below 80 million dollars, much less than Eurofighter, which does not have the advantages of F-35, Venable pointed out.
PAP's interlocutors expressed their hope that the final negotiations on the purchase of American fighter planes by Poland will be completed this year.
Possible participation of Polish subcontractors in this transaction - i.e. offset - will be discussed directly with American F-35 fighter manufacturers.
What is the Münchhausen replacement band referred to in the series "Payton Hobart Elections" on the Netflix platform?
Guardians and parents with the above mentioned disorder pretend that their healthy child is sick.
The series "Payton Hobert's Choices" will be launched on the Netflix platform today.

In the series Ryan Murphy, creator of "American Horror Story" and "Glee", we will see Gwyneth Paltrow, Ben Platt and Lucy Boynton.

Without revealing too many details for those who have not yet had the opportunity to see the series, it addresses the subject of Münchhausen's replacement syndrome - a mental illness that occurs in carers who act as if the healthy person they are dealing with were affected by a physical or mental illness.
There are different types of this disease, e.g. Münchhausen's syndrome, which causes symptoms of the disease.
Münchhausen's replacement team simulates that the person in our care has certain ailments.
It is also called an imaginary and induced disease, and is treated as violence against the child.
This is a rare condition that usually involves a parent exaggerating or causing symptoms so that it looks like their child is sick.
What are the symptoms of Münchhausen's replacement syndrome?
Symptoms of this disease may vary, but the NHS notes the following examples of behaviour:
Persuading the medical personnel that a child who looks healthy, however, feels bad.
Exaggerating or inventing symptoms.
Falsifying the results so that the child is considered sick, e.g. giving glucose to urine samples to make it look like the child has diabetes.
Causing symptoms of the disease, e.g. giving children unnecessary medicines and other substances.
How often does Münchhausen's replacement band perform?
It is difficult to estimate how often this disorder occurs because many cases are not reported.
A study published in 2000 indicates that there have been 89 cases of this disorder per 100,000 people in over two years.
What should be done if there are suspicions that the child may be in danger?
Contact your local Secret Service branch or call the NSPCC Child Protection Helpline on 0808 800 5000.

The Pope calls on the executive directors of technology companies to use artificial intelligence for the common good

On Friday, Pope Francis warned the executive directors of technology companies, diplomats, and financiers that the race to create artificial intelligence and other forms of digital achievement is threatening to increase social inequalities if it does not consider the common good from an ethical point of view.
Pope Francis gave these words at a conference at the Vatican, attended by government envoys and representatives of Facebook and Google, as well as philosophers, physicists and ethicists.
A small group of academics and bishops of the Catholic Church gathered the participants at the conference entitled "The future of the Catholic Church. "The Common Good in the Digital Age".
This three-day event is the latest proof that the Vatican is interested in participating in the debate on the prospects and threats of artificial intelligence.

The discussion focused on technological developments in the art of war and the future of work, in connection with which machines will play an increasingly important role, as well as a case study investigating the Christchurch assassination attempt in New Zealand and the decisions made by social media companies in connection with the spread of the film recording the massacre.

During his speech at the conference, Pope Francis praised the potential of technological progress, noting that machines at the beginning of the industrial revolution saved workers from dangerous and monotonous work.
He warned, however, that the increasing dependence on robotic devices for profit is a risk of depriving people of their dignity resulting from work.
If technological progress were to become the cause of increasingly visible inequalities, it would not be true and real progress, he warned.

If the so-called technological progress of mankind were to become an enemy of the common good, it would lead to undesirable backwardness to some kind of barbarism dictated by the law of the strongest.
The organizers of the conference expressed their hope to use the expertise of the participants and to identify possible future advisors of the Catholic Church on high technology issues.
